framework_intro.para:
Here is a framework to help you do a piece of reflective writing. There are spaces for you to add your own text.
Remember that you can double-click on any word to look it up in the dictionary.

commentary.para: Academic learning is not simply acquiring new knowledge; it also involves developing skills and new ways of thinking. Reflective writing asks students to think critically about the course and themselves as learners.

You may be asked to reflect on an experience, such as a field trip, on specific aspects of a task, such as how you chose a topic, or on your course as a whole. The writing may be a task on its own or a final section to an assignment such as a research report or an oral presentation.

You will need to show evidence that you are developing relevant skills and attitudes, that you can question your initial assumptions, and that you can connect theory and practice. You do this by reflecting on how a particular theory relates to your personal experience of an event or a situation.
You can use this outline to structure your reflective writing or vary it as necessary.
The model text is from a student reflecting on course material.
The writer will need to limit the comments on personal development to those that can be linked to specific literature and learning.
Your introduction previews your themes, and shows awareness of the academic context.
Giving a reference to a key academic related to your course demonstrates that you are aware of the important writers and researchers in your field.
Connect what you have read to what you have personally experienced.
The three abstract nouns listed preview the structure of the text—each one is further discussed in the following paragraphs. This gives coherence to the text as a whole.
The writer admits a previous mistaken belief. If you feel you have changed your thinking about a topic, it is useful to include this.
Giving concrete examples helps your reader. Make sure that if you generalize you have some examples for clarification.
The writer summarizes the lesson learnt by making a generalization. Moving from evidence to implication in this way helps your reader follow your points.
Give specific examples to back up your claims, e.g. for a change in your thinking and behaviour.
Even if this event is negative in some way, it is effective to show how you have learnt from the problem.

This paragraph shows self-awareness. You do not need to have completely gained a skill—it is usually enough to reflect honestly on how you are changing, and admit to weaknesses that you are working on.
In this paragraph the writer compares present feelings / skills with earlier ones - this also indicates that it is an on-going development.
The writer shows awareness of relevant literature.
Reflective writing that is assessed should have a balance of academic rigour and personal reflection; neither one should overshadow the other.
Make reference to the words of your assignment task in your conclusion.
Look to the future too—what changes in yourself or the situation do you expect to see?
Use the personal pronouns ‘I’ and ‘me’ to make personal claims.
The present perfect tense and the present continuous tense express an unfinished, on-going process. It is effective if you can show that you are changing and are open to development.
Word and phrases to compare and contrast

checklist.point: Read the assignment brief carefully and decide what the limits of the task are. What exactly do you need to reflect on?
Make notes on academic sources that might be useful—choose a good quotation or write a summarizing statement.
List events, key incidents or examples that will support your case.
Compose a draft, writing freely.
Look for themes in your draft and rearrange your writing around topics.
Give your writing an introduction that previews your themes, and shows awareness of the academic context.
Use academic language.

Language Bank: Expressing what you have learnt
Language Bank: Expressing a change in your thinking
Language Bank: Expressing positive changes
Language Bank: Admitting weaknesses
Evaluative adjectives
Grammar focus: use of tenses
Think about the writing process.
Have I reflected on exactly what the task asks me to?
Have I used some academic sources?
Have I used specific events or examples to support my case?
Have I shown self-awareness e.g. how I have changed or what I still need to do?
Does my work follow a clear structure, with an introduction that puts the essay in the academic context?
Have I referred to the words of the task in my conclusion?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?

content.para: The Impact of the Introduction to Stage Two Counselling Skills on my Personal Development

paragraph.name: Move 1: Connecting theory to practice
paragraph.desc: This connects the theory you have studied to your experience.

paragraph.name: Steps 1 and 2
paragraph.desc:
Step 1. Set out the general framework, using a quotation if relevant.
Step 2. Connect the theory to your experience.
paragraph.tip: TIP Connect what you have read to what you have personally experienced.

content.para: Carl Rogers arguedthat becoming a counsellor is not just the acquiring of a set of skills, but is a way of being; utilizing the three core conditions is a key aspect of this(Sanders, 2002: 67). Since embarking on the Introduction to Counselling Skills course,I have been made aware of Rogers' core conditionsofgenuineness,empathyandacceptance.I believe I possessed elements of these unknowingly; however, becoming conscious of them has enabled me to incorporate them into my being and to develop personally.

paragraph.name: Move 2: Internal changes
paragraph.desc: This examines your own feelings and behaviour and any changes that have taken place.

paragraph.name: Steps 1 and 2
paragraph.desc:
Step 1. Explore the reasons for your feelings and behaviour, or for those of others.
Step 2. Describe any changes that have taken place in your thinking.
paragraph.tip: TIP Giving concrete examples helps your reader.

content.para: The Counselling Skills course has taught me the importance of listening to others attentively. I thought that this was a skill I always held. However, on reflection, I noticed that I would often be preoccupied with other endeavours,such as watching television or sending a text. Recently, I have made a conscious effort to give my full attention to conversations and I have begun to notice when others do not offer me the same courtesy. This is sometimes hurtful. Listening to people and showing my interest and genuineness is a valuable skill to have and one that makes other people feel appreciated.

paragraph.desc: This gives specific examples to back up your claims.

paragraph.name: Steps 1 and 2

Step 1. Describe the specific event or aspect you wish to focus on.

content.para: This course has also taught me the difference between ‘knowing’ how people feel and understanding how people may feel from their perspective. I have learnt that it is impossible to know exactly how someone else feels and to say that one does may distract attention away from their problem.For example, my course friends and I have found the first term back at university stressful and we frequently share our feelings about this. I am often tempted to tell them ‘I know exactly how you feel’. However, I am now more considered in my response and rephrase this to something like ‘I understand how you must be feeling’. This validates what the others have said whilst letting them know I appreciate their views.

content.para: I have also learnt the difference betweenempathizing and sympathizing;this is extremely beneficial to me.I am a person thatcan get caught up in other people's difficulties; this is neither helpful nor supportive.Much betteris to empathize and remain objective as this is both helpful and supportive and may enable the other person to progress.

paragraph.name: Move 5: Comparing past with present and future
paragraph.desc: This compares your present feelings and skills with your earlier ones and looks at what changes you expect to see in the future.

paragraph.name: Steps 1, 2 and 3
paragraph.desc:
Step 1. Compare your past thinking to your present thinking.
Step 2. Consider the implications for the future.
Step 3. Conclude your reflection with reference to the task brief and your future plans.

content.para: During the course, I have learnt that before you can understand others you must first understand yourself.Sutton and Stewart (2002: 20) argue that by gaining self-awareness our chances of becoming genuine and empathic increase.This course has provided me with an opportunity to reflect on my own thoughts and my belief system. As a result of this,I am becoming more awareof my prejudices and values and have learnt that, in order to develop an empathic understanding,I need to tryto suspend these so I can give a non-judgemental and respectful response. I am much more aware of how this challenges me personally. I would find it difficult to deal with racist, sexist or prejudiced people as this opposes how I have been brought up to think. However, I now understand that other people may have been brought up with a different belief system. As a result of the course,I feel more capable of being less judgemental.Looking inward is the biggest and perhaps most difficult element of the Counselling Skills module, but the one which has been most beneficial to my personal development.
